{{good article}} {{Infobox military person | name = Bessas | native_name = Βέσσας | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 470s | death_date = after 554 | birth_place = | death_place = | allegiance = [[Byzantine Empire]] | serviceyears = ca. 500–554 | rank = ''[[magister militum]]'' | battles = [[Anastasian War]], [[Iberian War]], [[Gothic War (535–554)|Gothic War]], [[Lazic War]] | battles_label = Wars }} '''Bessas''' ({{lang-el|Βέσσας}}, before 480 – after 554) was an East Roman ([[Byzantine]]) general of [[Goths|Gothic]] origin from [[Thrace]], primarily known for his career in the wars of [[Justinian I]] ([[reign]]ed 527–565). He distinguished himself against the [[Sassanid Persia]]ns in the [[Iberian War]] and under the command of [[Belisarius]] in the [[Gothic War (535-554)|Gothic War]], but after Belisarius' departure from [[Italy (Roman Empire)|Italy]] he failed to confront the resurgent Goths and was largely responsible for the [[Sack of Rome (546)|loss]] of [[Rome]] in 546. Returning east in disgrace, despite his advanced age he was appointed as commander in the [[Lazic War]]. There he redeemed himself with the recapture of [[Petra, Lazica|Petra]], but his subsequent idleness led Justinian to dismiss him and exile him to [[Abasgia]].
== Origin == According to the contemporary historian [[Procopius of Caesarea]], Bessas was born in the 470s and hailed from a noble [[Goths|Gothic]] family long established in [[Thrace]], belonging to those Goths who had not followed [[Theodoric the Great]] when he left in 488 to invade [[Italy (Roman Empire)|Italy]], then held by [[Odoacer]].<ref name="PLRE226">Martindale, Jones & Morris (1980), p. 226</ref><ref>Amory (1997), pp. 98–99, 179</ref> Procopius remarks on his fluency in [[Gothic language|Gothic]],<ref name="PLRE226"/><ref>Amory (1997), p. 105</ref> but another contemporary writer, [[Jordanes]], claims that he hailed from the settlement of [[Castra Martis]], comprising [[Sarmatians]], [[Cemandrians]], and certain of the [[Huns]] (''[[Getica]]'' 265).<ref name="PLRE226"/> This evidence has been variously interpreted, with most modern commentators leaning towards a Gothic identity.<ref>cf. Amory (1997), pp. 364–365</ref> Nevertheless, according to [[Patrick Amory]], it is impossible from the sources at hand to draw any definite conclusion about his ethnicity. Amory maintains that Bessas was a typical example of the "blurry ethnographic identity" evidenced in 6th-century Balkan populations, especially among the military.<ref>Amory (1997), pp. 277ff.</ref>
== Career in the east == [[File:Roman-Persian Frontier in Late Antiquity.svg|thumb|right|225px|Map of the Byzantine-Persian frontier area.]] Very little is known of Bessas' early life and career: he joined the [[East Roman army|imperial army]] in his youth and according to Procopius was already "experienced in war" by 503, when the [[Anastasian War]] with the [[Sassanid Persia]]ns broke out. He took part in the war as an officer, but nothing is known of his service there.<ref name="PLRE226"/> On the other hand, he is probably to be identified with a ''[[comes]]'' of the same name who was addressed in a letter of the bishop [[Jacob of Serugh]] (d. 521).<ref name="PLRE226"/> If this identification is valid, then Bessas was a (probably moderate) [[Monophysite]].<ref>Amory (1997), p. 274</ref>
Bessas reappears in 531, during the [[Iberian War]] against Persia, when he was appointed ''[[dux Mesopotamiae]]'', with [[Silvan, Diyarbakır|Martyropolis]] as his base. In this capacity, Bessas led 500 cavalry against the Persian force guarding the same frontier sector, comprising 700 infantry and cavalry under the generals Gadar and Yazdgerd. The Byzantines engaged the Persians in battle on the banks of the [[Tigris]] and routed them, killing Gadar and taking Yazdgerd captive. Bessas then raided the province of [[Arzanene]] and returned to Martyropolis.<ref name="PLRE226"/><ref>Greatrex & Lieu (2002), p. 94</ref> In retaliation for this Byzantine success, the Persian shah [[Kavadh I]] sent against Martyropolis a large army commanded by three senior generals, [[Bawi]], [[Mihr-Mihroe]] and [[Chanaranges]]. The Persians besieged the city through the autumn, digging trenches and [[mining (military)|mines]], but the garrison, under Bessas and [[Bouzes]], held firm. Finally, the approach of winter, the arrival of large Byzantine forces at nearby [[Amida (Mesopotamia)|Amida]], and the news of the death of Kavadh forced the Persian commanders to raise the siege (in November or December).<ref name="PLRE226"/><ref>Greatrex & Lieu (2002), pp. 95–96</ref> Soon after their withdrawal, a force of [[Sabir people|Sabir Huns]], who the Persians had hired as mercenaries, invaded Roman territory and raided as far as [[Antioch]], but Bessas caught one of their raiding parties and destroyed it, capturing 500 horses and much booty.<ref name="PLRE226"/><ref>Greatrex & Lieu (2002), p. 95</ref>
== Actions in Italy == In 535, Bessas was appointed as one of [[Belisarius]]' lieutenants (along with Constantine and [[Peranius]]) in the expedition against the [[Ostrogothic kingdom]] of Italy.<ref>Martindale, Jones & Morris (1980), pp. 226–227</ref><ref>Bury (1958), p. 170</ref> He accompanied Belisarius in the early stages of the campaign, from the recovery of [[Sicily]] to the [[Siege of Naples (536)|siege]] of [[Naples]], and was present at the latter's fall in November 536.<ref>Bury (1958), pp. 171–177</ref><ref name="PLRE227">Martindale, Jones & Morris (1980), p. 227</ref> From there the Byzantine army advanced on [[Rome]], which it captured without a fight. Belisarius sent Constantine and Bessas to capture various outlying towns, but when he learned that the new Gothic king, [[Witiges]], was marching on Rome, he recalled them. Bessas tarried for a while near the town of [[Narni]], which controlled the [[Via Flaminia|direct route]] from the Gothic capital, [[Ravenna]], over the [[Apennines]] to Rome, and there met and defeated the Gothic vanguard in a skirmish.<ref name="PLRE227"/><ref>Bury (1958), p. 181</ref>
During the [[Siege of Rome (537–538)|year-long siege]] of Rome by the Goths, Bessas commanded the troops at the [[Porta Praenestina]] gate and distinguished himself in a number of skirmishes.<ref name="PLRE227"/> Nothing is known of his role in the subsequent events until 540, except that it was probably at about this time that he was raised to the rank of ''[[patrikios|patricius]]''.<ref name="PLRE227"/> In early 538, Bessas had protected Belisarius when the general Constantine tried to kill him during a dispute,<ref name="PLRE227"/><ref>Bury (1958), pp. 191–192</ref> but by 540, when Belisarius was preparing to enter Ravenna under pretense of accepting the Gothic offer to become [[Western Roman Empire|Emperor of the West]], he clearly felt that Bessas could not be trusted, and sent him, along with other troublemaking generals such as [[John (nephew of Vitalian)|John]] and [[Narses]], to occupy remote locations in Italy.<ref name="PLRE227"/><ref>Bury (1958), pp. 212–213</ref>
Following the departure of Belisarius in mid-540, Bessas remained in Italy. Justinian did not appoint an overall commander to replace Belisarius, and as a result the various Byzantine generals left in Italy failed to co-ordinate their actions. Instead of subduing the last remnants of the Ostrogoths in northern Italy, they retreated to the safety of various fortified cities, allowing the Goths to gather around a new leader, [[Ildibad]]. Ildibad marched on [[Treviso]] and routed a Byzantine force under Vitalius, whereupon Bessas advanced with his troops to [[Piacenza]].<ref name="PLRE227"/><ref>Bury (1958), pp. 227–228</ref> In late 541, after [[Totila]] had become king of the Goths, Bessas and the other Byzantine commanders assembled in Ravenna to co-ordinate their efforts, but the imperial troops were [[Siege of Verona|repulsed]] from [[Verona]] and [[Battle of Faventia|defeated]] at [[Faventia]] by Totila's Goths. The Goths then invaded [[Tuscany]] and threatened [[Florence]], held by the general [[Justin (general under Justinian I)|Justin]]. Bessas, along with John and Cyprian, marched to Justin's aid. The Goths retreated before the Byzantine reinforcements, but as the latter pursued, the Goths fell upon them and [[Battle of Mucellium|drove them to flight]]. After this new defeat the Byzantine commanders dispersed again to various cities and abandoned each other to his fate. Bessas withdrew with his forces to [[Spoleto]].<ref name="PLRE227"/><ref>Bury (1958), pp. 230–231</ref>
Nothing is known of his activities from then until early 545, by which time he was the garrison commander of Rome. Along with the general [[Conon (general under Justinian I)|Conon]] he was responsible for the city's defence during the [[Siege of Rome (546)|siege]] by Totila in 546.<ref>Bury (1958), pp. 235–236</ref><ref>Martindale, Jones & Morris (1980), pp. 227–228</ref> During the siege he restricted himself to passive defence, refusing to sally forth from the walls even when Belisarius, who had returned from the east and landed with reinforcements at the nearby [[Portus Romanus]], ordered him to do so. As a result, Belisarius' attempts to succour the beleaguered city failed.<ref>Bury (1958), pp. 239–242</ref><ref name="PLRE228">Martindale, Jones & Morris (1980), p. 228</ref> Procopius heavily criticizes Bessas for his conduct during the siege. He neglected of the civilian population of the city and enriched himself by selling the starving populace the grain he had hoarded at exorbitant prices. The civilians were so exhausted by famine that when he finally allowed those who wanted to leave the city to do so, many simply died on the wayside, while others were killed by the Goths.<ref name="PLRE228"/><ref>Bury (1958), pp. 238–239</ref> Finally, he proved negligent in the conduct of the defence, and allowed security measures to grow lax: guards slept at their posts, and patrols were discontinued. This allowed four [[Isauria]]n soldiers to contact Totila, and on 17 December 546, the city was betrayed to the Goths. Bessas managed to escape with the greater part of the garrison, but the treasure that he had amassed was left behind for the Goths to enjoy.<ref name="PLRE228"/><ref>Bury (1958), p. 242</ref> Following his dismal performance in Italy, Bessas was apparently recalled to [[Constantinople]].<ref name="PLRE228"/>
== Return to the eastern front and command in Lazica == [[File:Lazica in Late Antiquity.svg|thumb|225px|Map of Lazica and surrounding regions in [[Late Antiquity]]]] Bessas re-appears in 550, following the failure of a large Byzantine army under the ''[[magister militum]] per [[Roman Armenia|Armeniam]]'' [[Dagisthaeus]] to capture the strategic fortress of [[Petra, Lazica|Petra]] in the [[Lazic War|ongoing war]] with the Persians over [[Lazica]] (western [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]). To general surprise—and considerable criticism, in view of his advanced age and failure at Rome—Justinian named Bessas as Dagisthaeus' successor and entrusted him with the conduct of the war in Lazica.<ref name="PLRE228"/><ref>Bury (1958), pp. 113–114</ref>
Bessas first sent an expeditionary force to suppress a rebellion among the [[Abasgians]], who neighboured Lazica to the north. The expedition, under [[John Guzes]], was successful, and the Abasgian leader [[Opsites of Lazica|Opsites]] was forced to flee across the [[Caucasus]] to the Sabir Huns.<ref>Bury (1958), pp. 114–116</ref><ref>Greatrex & Lieu (2002), p. 118</ref> In spring 551, after a long siege and thanks largely to his own perseverance and bravery, the Byzantines and their Sabir allies (some 6,000 troops) captured Petra. A few Persians continued to resist from the citadel, but Bessas ordered it torched. Following his victory, he ordered the city walls razed to the ground.<ref name="PLRE228"/><ref>Bury (1958), p. 116</ref><ref>Greatrex & Lieu (2002), pp. 118–119</ref>
If the capture of Petra redeemed Bessas in the eyes of his contemporaries, his subsequent actions tarnished it again: instead of following up his success and capture the mountain passes connecting Lazica with the Persian province of [[Caucasian Iberia|Iberia]], he retired west to the Roman provinces of [[Diocese of Pontus|Pontica]] and busied himself with its administration.<ref>Martindale, Jones & Morris (1980), pp. 228–229</ref> This inactivity allowed the Persians under Mihr-Mihroe to consolidate Persian control over the eastern part of Lazica. The Byzantine forces in Lazica withdrew west to the mouth of the [[Phasis (river)|Phasis]], while the Lazi, including their king [[Gubazes II of Lazica|Gubazes]] and his family, sought refuge in the mountains. Despite enduring harsh conditions in the winter of 551–552, Gubazes rejected the peace offers conveyed by envoys from Mihr-Mihroe. In 552, the Persians received substantial reinforcements, but their attacks on the fortresses held by the Byzantines and the Lazi were repulsed.<ref>Greatrex & Lieu (2002), pp. 119–120</ref>
Bessas reappears in the campaign of 554, when he was appointed joint commander in Lazica with [[Martin (general under Justinian I)|Martin]], Bouzes and [[Justin (consul 540)|Justin]]. Gubazes, though, soon protested to Justinian about the incompetence of the Byzantine generals. Bessas was dismissed, his property was confiscated, and he was sent in exile among the Abasgians. Nothing more is known about him thereafter.<ref>Bury (1958), p. 118</ref><ref>Greatrex & Lieu (2002), p. 120</ref><ref>Martindale, Jones & Morris (1980), p. 229</ref>
